open_questions.title: CSS
open_questions.description: What is CSS?

open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: CSS (Cascading Style Sheets) is a markup language used for styling and formatting web pages, controlling elements' visual presentation, such as colors, fonts, spacing, and layout.

Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: The CSS Box Model
open_questions.description: Explain the CSS Box Model?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "Explain the CSS Box Model?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text:
The CSS Box Model is a concept that defines how an HTML element is structured, with content at its core, surrounded by padding, border, and margin layers that control its size, spacing, and appearance. Example: html
This is a box with content.
width and height set the dimensions of the content area. padding creates space between the content and the border. border defines a border around the content with a 2-pixel solid line. margin sets space around the border to control the element's spacing from other elements.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: The advantages of using CSS
open_questions.description: What are the advantages of using CSS?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What are the advantages of using CSS?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Separation of Content and Design: Allows styling without altering HTML structure. Efficiency: Reduces code duplication by applying styles to multiple elements. Flexibility: Easy to update and maintain website aesthetics. Responsive Design: Facilitates creation of responsive web layouts. Cross-Browser Compatibility: Ensures consistent look across different browsers. Accessibility: Improves website accessibility for various users and devices.

open_questions.title: The limitations of CSS
open_questions.description: What are the limitations of CSS?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What are the limitations of CSS?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Dynamic Functionality: CSS can't perform logical operations or complex calculations like programming languages. Browser Inconsistencies: Different browsers may interpret CSS differently, leading to inconsistent designs. Limited Selector Control: CSS lacks parent selectors and some complex selectors. Scalability Issues: Managing CSS in large-scale projects can be challenging due to global scope and cascading rules. Limited Variables and Functions: Before CSS preprocessors, CSS lacked native variables and functions for complex tasks.

Give a small example

open_questions.title: The difference between inline, inline-block, and
open_questions.description: What is the difference between inline, inline-block, and block?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What is the difference between inline, inline-block, and block?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Inline: Elements don't start on a new line, and only occupy necessary width. No width/height setting; margin and padding affect only horizontally. Block: Elements start on a new line and occupy the full width available. Width/height can be set; margin and padding affect all sides. Inline-Block: Mix of inline and block. Elements flow like inline but can have width/height like block.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: Does margin-top or margin-bottom have an
open_questions.description: Does margin-top or margin-bottom have an effect on inline elements?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "Does margin-top or margin-bottom have an effect on inline elements?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: No, margin-top and margin-bottom do not affect inline elements in CSS. Inline elements respect margin-left and margin-right, but not vertical margins (margin-top and margin-bottom). This is due to the nature of inline elements, which flow within the text and don't disrupt the vertical line flow. For vertical spacing on inline elements, other methods such as line-height or padding might be used, or changing the element's display type.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: You use media queries for mobile
open_questions.description: How can you use media queries for mobile devices?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "How can you use media queries for mobile devices?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Media queries in CSS are used to apply styles based on device characteristics, such as screen size. For mobile devices, common practices include: Setting Viewport: Include a viewport meta tag in the HTML head for proper scaling. <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1">. Defining Breakpoints: Create media queries for specific screen sizes. For example: html @media screen and (max-width: 600px) { /* Styles for screens smaller than 600px */ }
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Responsive Web Design is an approach to web design aimed at crafting sites to provide an optimal viewing and interaction experience across a wide range of devices. Key features include: Fluid Grids: Layouts that scale gracefully to fit any screen size. Flexible Images: Images that resize within their containing elements. Media Queries: CSS techniques that apply styles based on device characteristics.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: The order in which styles are
open_questions.description: Explain the order in which styles are applied in CSS.?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "Explain the order in which styles are applied in CSS.?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: The order in which styles are applied in CSS is determined by a combination of three main factors: specificity, source order, and inheritance. Specificity: This is the primary factor. Specificity is a measure of how precisely a CSS selector matches a set of elements. Selectors with higher specificity override those with lower specificity. Source Order: When two selectors have the same specificity, the one that appears later in the CSS code takes precedence. This is known as the source order rule. It means that if you have two equally specific rules, the second one will override the first one. Inheritance: Some CSS properties are inherited by child elements from their parent elements, unless overridden. For example, font and color properties are often inherited. This means that if you set a property on a parent element, it can affect the child elements unless they have their own specific rules. Importance: The !important declaration in CSS can override the specificity and source order. When !important is used on a CSS property, it becomes the most important and overrides other properties, regardless of their specificity or source order.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: Contextual selectors
open_questions.description: What are contextual selectors?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What are contextual selectors?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Contextual selectors in CSS target elements based on their relationships within the HTML structure: Descendant Selector (A B): Targets element B that is a descendant of A. Child Selector (A > B): Targets element B that is a direct child of A. Adjacent Sibling Selector (A + B): Targets element B that immediately follows A. General Sibling Selector (A ~ B): Targets all elements B that follow A.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: Flexbox
open_questions.description: What is Flexbox?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What is Flexbox?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Flexbox, or the Flexible Box Module, is a layout model in CSS that provides a more efficient way to lay out, align, and distribute space among items in a container, even when their size is unknown or dynamic. Key features: Direction-Agnostic: Unlike traditional layouts (block is vertically-based, inline is horizontally-based), Flexbox works in any direction. Container Properties: Control the layout's direction, wrap, alignment, and spacing. Item Properties: Control the order, alignment, flexibility, and size of the items. Responsive Layout: Flexbox makes it easier to design a flexible responsive layout structure without using floats or positioning.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

referenceAnswers.text: Accessibility (abbreviated as "a11y" where "11" stands for the 11 letters omitted) refers to the design and creation of websites, tools, and technologies that are usable by all people, including those with disabilities.

open_questions.title: Es the calc() function do
open_questions.description: What does the calc() function do?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What does the calc() function do?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: The calc() function in CSS performs calculations to determine property values, combining different units like percentages, pixels, ems, etc. It supports basic arithmetic operations: addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division. For example, width: calc(100% - 50px) calculates a width that is the full container width minus 50 pixels. It's useful for responsive design and dynamic sizing.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: CSS Custom properties variables
open_questions.description: What are CSS Custom properties variables?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What are CSS Custom properties variables?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: CSS Custom Properties, often referred to as CSS Variables, are entities defined by CSS authors that contain specific values to be reused throughout a document. They follow this format: Definition: Custom properties are set using the syntax --propertyName: value;. For example, --main-color: blue;. Usage: They are accessed using the var() function, like color: var(--main-color);.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: The difference between CSS variables and
open_questions.description: What is the difference between CSS variables and Pre-processor Variables (SASS, LESS, Stylus)?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What is the difference between CSS variables and Pre-processor Variables (SASS, LESS, Stylus)?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Scope and Runtime: CSS Variables can be changed at runtime and have actual scope within the CSS DOM, while pre-processor variables are compiled into static CSS and can't be changed post-compilation. Processing: CSS Variables are processed in the browser, allowing dynamic changes. Pre-processor variables are processed during the server-side build process. Compatibility: CSS Variables are supported in modern browsers but not in older ones, whereas pre-processor variables work in all browsers as they compile into standard CSS. Dynamic Capabilities: CSS Variables can be manipulated with JavaScript at runtime, unlike static pre-processor variables.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: The major differences between CSS3 and
open_questions.description: What are the major differences between CSS3 and CSS2?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What are the major differences between CSS3 and CSS2?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Modules: CSS3 is split into modules (like Selectors, Box Model, Backgrounds and Borders) for easier maintenance and updates. CSS2 was a single, monolithic specification. New Features: CSS3 introduced new features like animations, transitions, gradients, flexbox, grid layout, and media queries for responsive design. CSS2 lacked these advanced features. Browser Compatibility: CSS3 features are often implemented progressively across browsers, while CSS2 features generally have wider and more consistent support. Syntax and Capabilities: CSS3 supports more complex selectors and properties, offering greater flexibility and control in styling compared to CSS2.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: Es !important mean in CSS
open_questions.description: What does !important mean in CSS?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What does !important mean in CSS?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: In CSS, !important is used to override other style rules, making the specified rule take precedence regardless of specificity. Its use is discouraged as it complicates CSS maintenance and debugging. For example, color: red !important; will ensure the element's text color is red, even if other style rules target the same element with different color values.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

referenceAnswers.text: static: Default value; elements flow in the order they appear in HTML. relative: Positioned relative to its normal position, allowing top, right, bottom, left adjustments. absolute: Positioned relative to the nearest positioned ancestor, removed from the normal flow. fixed: Positioned relative to the viewport, stays in place during scrolling. sticky: Behaves like static until scrolled to a certain point, then acts like fixed.

referenceAnswers.text: CSS transitions enable smooth changes to property values over a specified duration. They're used for creating animations when a CSS property changes, like on hover. For example, transition: background-color 0.5s ease; smoothly changes the background color over half a second when the element state changes. Common usage includes animating color changes, altering size, and moving elements.

open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: CSS allows different media types for applying styles to specific devices or presentations: all: Suitable for all devices. print: Intended for printed materials and PDFs. screen: Primarily for computer screens. speech: Intended for speech synthesizers.

Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: The different units used in CSS
open_questions.description: What are the different units used in CSS?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What are the different units used in CSS?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: In CSS, units are used to specify sizes, lengths, and distances. The main types are: Absolute Units: Fixed and consistent. Examples include pixels (px), points (pt), inches (in), centimeters (cm), millimeters (mm). Relative Units: Scale relative to other elements or the viewport. Examples include percentages (%), ems (em), rems (rem), viewport width (vw), viewport height (vh).
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: The overflow property in CSS used
open_questions.description: What is the overflow property in CSS used for?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What is the overflow property in CSS used for?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: The overflow property in CSS specifies how to handle content that's too big to fit in its box. It can be set to: visible: Overflowing content is not clipped and renders outside the box. hidden: Content is clipped and no scrollbars are provided. scroll: Content is clipped and scrollbars are added, even if unnecessary. auto: Browser decides whether to add scrollbars when needed.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: The concept of specificity in CSS.
open_questions.description: Explain the concept of specificity in CSS.?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "Explain the concept of specificity in CSS.?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: In CSS, specificity determines which style rules apply when multiple rules target the same element. It's calculated based on the types and number of selectors used in a rule, with inline styles having the highest specificity, followed by IDs, then classes, attributes, and pseudo-classes, and finally, element and pseudo-element selectors. The rule with higher specificity overrides others.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: VH/VW (viewport height/ viewport width) in
open_questions.description: What is VH/VW (viewport height/ viewport width) in CSS?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What is VH/VW (viewport height/ viewport width) in CSS?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: In CSS, VH (Viewport Height) and VW (Viewport Width) are relative units that measure size as a percentage of the viewport (the browser window's visible area). 1vh is 1% of the viewport's height. 1vw is 1% of the viewport's width.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: Vendor prefixes
open_questions.description: What are Vendor prefixes?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What are Vendor prefixes?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Vendor prefixes in CSS are a way for browser manufacturers to introduce support for new CSS features before they become standardized. These prefixes ensure that the experimental or non-standard features can be used in specific browsers, without affecting how the page is rendered in browsers that don't support these features yet. Common vendor prefixes include: -webkit- for Chrome, Safari, newer versions of Opera. -moz- for Firefox. -ms- for Internet Explorer and Microsoft Edge. -o- for older versions of Opera. Example: css background: -webkit-linear-gradient(red, blue); /* Chrome, Safari, Opera */ background: -moz-linear-gradient(red, blue); /* Firefox */ background: -ms-linear-gradient(red, blue); /* IE */ background: -o-linear-gradient(red, blue); /* Old Opera */ background: linear-gradient(red, blue); /* Standard syntax */
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: Pseudo-classes
open_questions.description: What are pseudo-classes?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What are pseudo-classes?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Pseudo-classes in CSS are keywords added to selectors that specify a special state of the selected elements. They allow you to define a particular style for an element when it's in a certain state. Examples: :hover: Styles the element when its hovered over by a cursor. :focus: Applies style when the element is focused (like input fields). :active: Styles the element during the time its activated (like when a button is clicked). :visited and :link: Style links depending on whether they have been visited. :first-child and :last-child: Targets the first or last child element within its parent. :nth-child(): Styles an element based on its position in a group of siblings.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: Es the :root pseudo-class refer to

Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: The :root pseudo-class in CSS refers to the highest-level parent element in the document, typically the HTML element. It's commonly used in defining global CSS variables and styles that can be applied universally across the webpage. For example, defining CSS variables in :root makes them accessible throughout the entire document, facilitating consistent styling and easy theme management.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: A rule set in CSS, and
open_questions.description: What is a rule set in CSS, and how do you implement one?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What is a rule set in CSS, and how do you implement one?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: A rule set in CSS consists of a selector and a declaration block. The selector targets HTML elements, and the declaration block contains one or more declarations that style the selected elements. Each declaration includes a property and a value, separated by a colon and enclosed in curly braces. To implement a rule set: Choose a Selector: Determine which HTML element(s) you want to style. For example, p for paragraphs. Create Declaration Block: Define the CSS properties and their values. For example, color: blue; font-size: 16px;. Combine Selector and Declaration Block: Place the declaration block within curly braces after the selector. Example of a rule set: css p { color: blue; font-size: 16px; }
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: The difference between grouping and nesting
open_questions.description: What is the difference between grouping and nesting?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What is the difference between grouping and nesting?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Grouping: Combining multiple selectors to apply the same styles to different elements. For example: css h1, h2, h3 { font-family: Arial; } Applies the same font to h1, h2, and h3 elements. Nesting: Used in CSS preprocessors like SASS, where you define styles for child elements inside the parent selector block. For example: scss nav { ul { margin: 0; li { list-style-type: none; } } }
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: You tween an object in CSS
open_questions.description: Why would you tween an object in CSS?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "Why would you tween an object in CSS?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Tweening an object in CSS, typically done through animations or transitions, is used to create smooth movement or transformation of the object over time. Reasons for tweening include: Enhancing User Experience: Smooth transitions and animations can make interactions more intuitive and visually appealing. Providing Visual Feedback: Tweening can indicate state changes, like hovering over a button. Guiding Attention: Animated objects can draw attention to important elements or changes on a page. Improving Aesthetics: Subtle animations can make a website feel more dynamic and polished. Narrative and Engagement: Animations can be used to tell a story or engage users interactively.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: The difference between {visibility: hidden} and
open_questions.description: What is the difference between {visibility: hidden} and {display: none}?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What is the difference between {visibility: hidden} and {display: none}?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: In CSS, {visibility: hidden} and {display: none} both hide an element, but in different ways: {visibility: hidden}: The element is invisible, but it still occupies its space in the layout. Other elements are positioned as if it's there. {display: none}: The element is removed from the document flow, and it doesn't take up any space. Other elements are laid out as if the element doesn't exist.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: The difference between reset vs normalize
open_questions.description: What is the difference between reset vs normalize CSS?

Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Reset CSS: Removes all built-in browser styling. Standard elements like h1, ul, p start with the same style, providing a clean slate for custom styling. Normalize CSS: Makes built-in styles consistent across browsers while preserving useful defaults. It corrects common bugs and improves usability without flattening all styles.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

referenceAnswers.text: Gradients in CSS create a smooth transition between two or more specified colors. They can be linear or radial: Linear Gradients: Transition along a straight line, defined by an angle or direction. Syntax: css background: linear-gradient(direction, color1, color2, ...); Radial Gradients: Transition outward in a circular or elliptical shape from a central point. Syntax: css background: radial-gradient(shape size at position, start-color, ..., last-color);

Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

referenceAnswers.text: Pseudo-elements in CSS are used for styling specific parts of an element: Content Insertion: ::before and ::after insert decorative content without altering HTML. Style Text Parts: ::first-line and ::first-letter style specific parts of text. Custom Selections: ::selection styles user-selected text. Placeholder Styling: ::placeholder styles the placeholder text of input fields.

open_questions.title: The CSS Grid System
open_questions.description: What is the CSS Grid System?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What is the CSS Grid System?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: The Grid System in CSS is a powerful layout mechanism that allows for the creation of complex, responsive web designs. It works by defining a container as a grid with rows and columns, enabling precise placement and alignment of elements within this grid structure. Key aspects: Grid Container: The element on which display: grid is applied. It becomes the framework for placing child elements in grid format. Grid Items: The direct children of the grid container, which can be positioned and aligned within the grid. Rows and Columns: The grid is divided into rows and columns, which can be explicitly defined or implicitly created based on the content. Grid Lines: The dividing lines that make up the structure of the grid. They can be used to place items and define areas. Grid Cells, Areas, and Gaps: Individual spaces formed by the grid (cells), larger areas spanning multiple cells, and the spacing between rows and columns (gaps). Responsiveness: The grid layout can be made responsive using media queries, fractional units, and repeat functions, allowing for flexible and adaptive web designs.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: DOM
open_questions.description: When does DOM reflow occur?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a mid-level candidate. Answer the question: "When does DOM reflow occur?" Requirements: - Explain in the browser runtime context - Give a practical example - Why it impacts performance - Concrete ways to reduce the cost Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Explain in the browser runtime context; Give a practical example; Why it impacts performance; Concrete ways to reduce the cost. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: DOM reflow occurs when there are changes to the layout of a web page, causing the browser to recalculate element positions and geometries. This can happen due to: Adding, Removing, or Updating DOM Elements: Changes to the document structure. Modifying CSS Styles: Changes in styling that affect layout. Manipulating the Browser Window: Resizing the window, scrolling, or changing orientation. Querying Layout Properties: Accessing certain properties like offsetWidth or scrollTop.
keyPoints: Explain in the browser runtime context
Give a practical example
Why it impacts performance
Concrete ways to reduce the cost

open_questions.title: The different ways to organize and
open_questions.description: What are the different ways to organize and structure CSS code in larger projects?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What are the different ways to organize and structure CSS code in larger projects?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Modular CSS: Breaking CSS into smaller, reusable modules, often aligning with components. Component-Based Architecture: Using methodologies like BEM (Block, Element, Modifier) to structure CSS around UI components. Preprocessors (SASS, LESS): Utilizing features like variables, mixins, and nesting for better organization and maintainability. CSS Frameworks: Implementing frameworks like Bootstrap or Tailwind CSS for a consistent and structured approach. CSS-in-JS: For projects using JavaScript frameworks, embedding CSS directly within JavaScript files. Utility-First CSS: Adopting utility-first frameworks like Tailwind CSS for a more functional approach. Documentation and Style Guides: Maintaining clear documentation and style guides to ensure consistency and clarity. File Organization: Structuring files logically, often mirroring the structure of the project's components.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: Es CSS work under the hood
open_questions.description: How does CSS work under the hood?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "How does CSS work under the hood?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Loading: The browser loads the CSS from external files, embedded style tags, or inline styles. Parsing: CSS is parsed into understandable rulesets. The parser resolves the selectors and properties. Conversion to Stylesheets: Parsed data is converted into stylesheets understood by the browser. Processing Rules: The browser matches selectors to corresponding nodes in the DOM (Document Object Model). Cascade and Inheritance: Rules are applied following the cascade and inheritance principles, with conflicts resolved by specificity and source order. Style Computation: The final values of CSS properties for each element are computed. Layout/Reflow: The browser calculates the position and size of each element. Painting: The visual representation of the page is created based on the layout. Compositing: Layers are combined and rendered on the screen.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: Functions/mixins
open_questions.description: What are functions/mixins?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What are functions/mixins?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: In the context of CSS pre-processors like SASS or LESS, functions and mixins are powerful features used for writing reusable and dynamic CSS code: Functions: Functions compute and return a value. They can take arguments and are used for calculations, color manipulations, and other operations that return a value. For example, a function might calculate a contrasting color or a responsive font size. Mixins: Mixins are blocks of reusable code that can be included in other CSS rules. They accept arguments and can be used to embed entire groups of CSS declarations into a rule. Mixins are ideal for vendor prefixing, grid layouts, font stacks, etc., allowing for more maintainable and DRY (Don't Repeat Yourself) code.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: Between logical and physical tags.
open_questions.description: Differentiate between logical and physical tags.?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "Differentiate between logical and physical tags.?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Logical tags in HTML convey semantic meaning, focusing on the content's purpose (e.g., <em>, <strong>, <article>), while physical tags define the visual appearance (e.g., <b>, <i>). Logical tags are preferred for accessibility and SEO, with styling handled by CSS rather than physical tags.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: Es a browser determine what elements
open_questions.description: How does a browser determine what elements match a CSS selector?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "How does a browser determine what elements match a CSS selector?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: When a browser determines which elements match a CSS selector, it follows these steps: Parsing CSS: The browser parses the CSS file, understanding the selectors and their corresponding styles. Building the DOM: It constructs the Document Object Model (DOM) from the HTML, representing the page structure. Selector Matching: The browser matches CSS selectors against the elements in the DOM. This process is done right-to-left; it first checks the key selector (the rightmost part), then moves leftwards in the rule. Applying Styles: Once an element is matched, the browser applies the corresponding CSS styles. If multiple rules match, it uses the cascade rules (specificity and source order) to determine which styles to apply. Rendering: The final step is rendering the page with the applied styles.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: PostCSS
open_questions.description: What is PostCSS?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What is PostCSS?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: PostCSS is a tool for transforming CSS with JavaScript plugins. It allows developers to automate routine CSS operations, incorporate future CSS syntax, and enhance CSS functionalities. Key features include: Autoprefixing: Automatically adds vendor prefixes to CSS rules. Future CSS Syntax: Use newer CSS features not yet supported in browsers. Optimizations: Minifies and optimizes CSS for better performance. Plugins: Extensible with a wide range of plugins for various tasks.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice

open_questions.title: The differences between adaptive design and
open_questions.description: What are the differences between adaptive design and responsive design?
open_questions.prompt: You are evaluating a junior-level candidate. Answer the question: "What are the differences between adaptive design and responsive design?" Requirements: - Define the concept in your own words - Give a small example - Mention a common pitfall or best practice Style: - Clear, structured, concise. - Use code snippets only if they add clarity. - Avoid vague statements.
open_questions.aiEvaluationHint: Expect the answer to address: Define the concept in your own words; Give a small example; Mention a common pitfall or best practice. Penalize answers that miss key requirements.

referenceAnswers.text: Responsive Design uses fluid grids and CSS media queries to create layouts that adapt seamlessly to various screen sizes, providing a continuous experience across devices with the same HTML content. Adaptive Design employs multiple fixed layouts tailored to specific screen sizes. The server detects the device and serves the corresponding layout, offering a discrete experience optimized for each device type.
keyPoints: Define the concept in your own words
Give a small example
Mention a common pitfall or best practice
